s.text: A high-energy physicist once told me, when I asked her what she was working on, "I couldn't possibly put it into words"--yet she continues to receive NSF funding, which suggests someone understands what she is up to on her grant applications.
Cultural-loyalty movements like the class in Navajo tend to spring up when cultural preservation is in danger, and their record of success is not impressive.

We are living in a time when English serves as an international language.
What interests me about these minority language and dialect matters is why ebonics was perceived as so great a threat when the whole issue arose in late 1996 in Oakland, Calif.
